awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding the chemical and physical variability of smoke using plume spatial gradients: analysis and parameterization for air quality and climate models
awd_abstract_narration:
This project includes an evaluation of observational data from three recent atmospheric chemistry field campaigns to measure pollutants in the plumes of wildfires. The observational data will used to develop and assess a new parameterization for modeling the variability in the pollutant aging processes across wildfire plumes. The new parameterization is expected to improve the predictive capability of air quality and climate models.

Recent observations suggest that gradients across a smoke plume include differences in photochemistry, aerosol composition, and aerosol size, likely driven by differences in dilution and UV radiation in different parts of the plume. By studying the differences between the plume edge/core and top/bottom, the investigators expect to provide a better understanding of the variability in aging between different plumes. The System for Atmospheric Modelling (SAM) - Aerosol Simulation Program (ASP) model, developed by Pierce and Alvarado with prior support from NSF, will be used to advance the understanding of pollution- and climate-relevant smoke aging processes. The data that will be used for this project includes: (1) the NSF-funded Western wildfire Experiment for Cloud chemistry, Aerosol absorption, and Nitrogen (WE-CAN) campaign held in July-September 2018; (2) the DOE-supported Biomass Burning Observation Project (BBOP) conducted during June-October 2013; and (3) the Fire Influence on Regional to Global Environments and Air Quality (FIREX-AQ) campaign, a joint NASA/NOAA venture, that occurred in the summer of 2019.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Wildfires, prescribed fires, and agricultural fires emit smoke that contained not only small soot and oil particles (particulate matter), but also a mixture of gases that can create ozone and more particulate matter. Exposure to the smoke thus increases the exposure of the general public to particulate matter and ozone, both of which are regulated air pollutants which can cause short-term and long-term damage to people’s health. This smoke can also alter the Earth’s climate, either directly by absorbing and reflecting sunlight, or indirectly by changing clouds and their interactions with the heat and water cycles of the planet.

The size of these effects depends not only on the amount of smoke but also on the changing composition of the smoke and the size of the particulate matter within the smoke. The concentrations of ozone and particulate matter vary between smoke plumes due to differences in the fire emissions and smoke evolution (aging) within each plume. Understanding smoke aging requires an understanding of the following processes within plumes: (1) net production of ozone, (2) net production of particulate matter, and (3) the change in the size of the particulate matter. Current air quality and climate models are generally unable to resolve the small size of smoke plumes near the fire source, and thus miss how the aging process changes due to location within the plume (top versus bottom, edge versus core). Hence, making progress in understanding smoke air quality and climate impacts requires a more complete understanding of smoke aging processes, which requires a new model that can represent the important processes taking place within aging smoke plumes and how these processes change with location within the plume.

In this project, we developed an improved plume-scale model of smoke aging called SAM-ASP to improve our understanding of the aging of smoke and how it changes with location within the smoke plume. We added a model of the reflection and absorption of sunlight by the smoke to SAM-ASP to better represent the changes in smoke aging as you move around the smoke plume. These simulations were used to better understand the aging of smoke within the Williams Flats fire from the NSF-funded WE-CAN field campaign. We found that the new model did a good job of explaining the formation of ozone and growth of particulate matter within the plume and showed how these aging processes differed with location within the plume. This work will help us to understand and predict the impacts of wildfire and other smoke on human health and the climate.
